Recognizing diseconomies of congestion and environmental degradation in metropolitan 
cities,  the  Government  has  requested  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  to  continue  to 
provide  assistance  to  the  urban  sector  for  rehabilitation  and  expansion  of  urban  development 
and services in secondary towns (Pourashavas) throughout the country, and to further assist in 
the  decentralization  and  strengthening  of  urban  governance.  In  response,  ADB  provided  two 
project  preparatory  technical  assistance  (PPTA)1 grants  to  undertake  a  feasibility  study  and 
project preparation. This Report is based on the findings of these PPTAs, and the discussions

Urbanization.  In  2001,  the  total  urban  population  in  Bangladesh  was  about  30  million, 
representing  approximately  23%  of  the  national  population.  While  this  level  of  urbanization  is 
relatively low by Asian standards, the urban population grew at an annual rate of about 3.5% in 
1991-2000,  compared  with  the  national  population  growth  rate  of  1.5%.  The  growth  rates  of 
Pourashavas range from relatively low in most (at around 2%), to moderately high (up to 4.5%) 
in a few cases. The growth of the urban population in Bangladesh is mainly due to the growth of 
metropolitan cities.  
 
4. 
Contribution to Economic Growth. Rapid urbanization has contributed to the growing 
share of the urban sector in overall economic growth. Over 40% of the country's gross domestic 
product (GDP) is now derived from the urban sector, from a low of 25% in the early 1970s. The 
Government’s  Fifth  Five-Year  Plan  (1997-2002)  projected  that  the  urban  sector  GDP  would 
grow  at  around  14%  per  annum,  which  is  more  than  twice  the  growth  target  for  the  national 
GDP.    
 
5. 
Urban  Poverty. The incidence of poverty in Bangladesh, as measured by the costs of 
basic  needs  poverty  line,  fell  from  58.8%  in  FY1992  to  49.8%  in  2000.  A  sector  breakdown 
shows  that  progress  in  reducing  poverty  was  almost  equal  across  urban  and  rural  areas:  the 
urban  headcount  ratio  declined  from  44.9%  to  36.6%  (by  8.3%)  while  rural  poverty  declined 
from 61.2% to 53.0% (by 8.2%). However, the moderate reduction in urban poverty during the 
last  decade  was  accompanied  by  a  notable  increase  in  urban  income  inequality,  as  the  Gini 
coefficient increased from 0.398 to 0.452.  

 
6. 
The  situations  have  been  somewhat  different  in  the  case  of  absolute  numbers  of  the 
poor in urban and rural areas. In FY1992, the number of urban poor population was 6.5 million 
when total urban population was 14.6 million. This then increased to 9.3 million in 2000. Thus 
there has been at least a 43% growth of the urban poor population during the last decade. The

current trend of migration continues, the urban poor will increase to 25-30% of the country's total 
poor by 2020, if not more. These facts point to the growing need to address urban poverty both 
as  an  aspect  of  a  new  dimension  of  poverty  (relative  to  rural  poverty)  and  as  a  matter  of 
increasing priority to reducing poverty. 
 
7. 
Urban Infrastructure and Basic Services.  There are deficiencies in all urban services. 
Only  30%  of  urban  households  use  tap  water  for  drinking,  and  probably  less  than  20%  have 
their  own  house  connections.  With  the  exception  of  a  limited  waterborne  sewerage  system  in 
Dhaka, no other urban center has any form of sewerage system. Solid waste collection levels 
are around 20%. Urban areas also suffer from severe traffic congestion and the absence of any 
form of mass public transit system. For most urban residents, housing conditions are very bad. 
Only 25% of urban households live in dwellings with permanent structure.  Very high land prices, 
insecurity of tenure, and a lack of housing finance have handicapped the growth of the formal 
sector of the housing market. In most urban centers, ambient air and water quality is extremely 
poor. The major sources of air pollution are traffic, brickfields, and industry. The major sources 
of  water  pollution  are  domestic  and  industrial  wastewater  discharges.  Inadequate  drainage 
increases the exposure of the urban population to the effects of polluted water.  
 
B. 
 
 
 
8. 
Recent  experience  in  Bangladesh  suggests  that  urbanization  needs  to  be  seen  in  a 
positive  light.  The  poverty  reducing  potential  of  well-planned  and  decentralized  urbanization  is 
immense,  especially  in  the  longer  term.  However,  unplanned  and  uncontrolled  urbanization 
creates  tremendous  pressure  on  basic  urban  infrastructure  and  eventually  limits  the  growth 
potential of the national economy. Moreover, the concentration of population and activities in a 
few  metropolitan  areas  tends  to  further  aggravate  urban  environmental  conditions  in  the 
absence of adequate capacity to manage urban growth (a summary of urban sector analysis is 
presented in Appendix 2).  
 
The  Government  is  therefore  developing  secondary  towns  to  improve  their  living

the  migration  to  the  larger  metropolitan  cities.  ADB  has  been  assisting  the  Government  to

Projects  I  and  II 3  (STIDP  I  and  II).  So  far,  ADB  has  supported  upgrading  of  municipal 
infrastructure  facilities  in  32  of  64  district  towns  in  Bangladesh.  The  World  Bank  is  currently

11. 
Urban  governance  is  broadly  defined  as  "the  sum  of  the  many  ways  individuals  and 
institutions, public and private, plan and manage the common affairs of the city.”4 Two aspects 
of this broad definition need further elaboration. First, it indicates that urban governance is not 
just government. Governance as a concept recognizes that decision-making power to improve 
the  affairs  of  the  city  exists  inside  and  outside  the  formal  authority  and  institutions  of 
government.  In  other  words,  governance  includes  the  government,  private  sector,  and  civil 
society.  The  second  aspect  emphasizes  that  urban  governance  is  a  "process."  It  is  a 
participatory  process  through  which  diverse  interests  of  the  city  may  be  accommodated  and 
cooperative action can be taken.  
 
12. 
Through  extensive  interviews  and  consultations  with  the  Pourashavas  during  the 
implementation  of  the  PPTA,  it  became  evident  that  most  of  the  Project  towns  have  a  poor 
record  in  terms  of  public  participation  in  urban  management.  Promoting  decentralization  of 
authority  and  powers  to  Pourashavas  will  not  produce  any  desirable  result  unless  there  is  a 
commensurate  increase  in  the  delegation  of  powers  from  the  Pourashava  chairpersons  to 
elected commissioners and to citizen groups. The key to the gains in efficiency associated with 
decentralization  is  the  accountability  of  elected  officials,  especially  the  chairpersons,  to  local 
residents.  Increasing  accountability  will  require  more  participation  of  citizens  in  Pourashava 
affairs.  
 
13. 
Overall,  there  are  two  outstanding  considerations  under  the  Project  for  improving 
Pourashava governance: First is a concern for the concentration of authority and powers in the 
hands of the Pourashava chairperson, which results in poor performance, inefficiency, and lack 
of accountability, much to the detriment of good governance. The second is a concern for weak 
capacity of elected commissioners, local public officials, and community groups; this becomes 
concern for the limited scope for increasing the role of municipal council, and ward and citizens 
committees in running municipal affairs.  
 
14. 
To effectively address these main concerns, an Urban Governance Improvement Action 
Program (UGIAP) has been developed in close consultation with the participating Pourashavas. 
Overall,  the  UGIAP  comprises  five  subprograms:  three  for  enhancing  the  awareness  and  the 
participation  of  local  stakeholders  in  urban  planning  and  management  (citizen  awareness  and 
participation,  women’s  participation,  and  integration  of  the  urban  poor)  and  two  for  improving 
accountability  and  transparency  (financial  accountability  and  sustainability,  and  administrative 
transparency). Under these subprograms, Pourashavas will be asked to form town-level citizens 
committees,  develop  participatory  municipal  development  plan,  strengthen  the  role  of  female 
ward  commissioners,  implement  poverty  reduction  action  programs,  operate  microcredit 
program for the poor women, and increase tax collection. 
 
15.  While the ultimate responsibility for urban governance rests with urban local bodies, the 
role  of  the  Central  Government  is  also  important.  On  the  fiscal  side,  the  Central  Government 
directly  supports  centrally  funded  municipal  projects  and  has  statutory  control  over  different 
aspects  of  municipal  revenues  and  expenditures.  A  central  government  ministry,  Ministry  of 
Local  Government,  Rural  Development  and  Cooperatives  (MLGRDC),  is  responsible  for 
supervision of municipal affairs, the scope of which includes demanding records, inspection of 
activities, and revoking illegal orders and decisions of municipal governments. Given the large 
number of the central government agencies involved in planning, building, and managing urban

SUMMARY OF URBAN SECTOR ANALYSIS 
 

A. 

Demographic and Spatial Trends 

 

Institutional Framework 

Bangladesh  has  experienced  significant  growth  in  urban  population  from  less  than  5 
1. 
million in 1971 to almost 30 million in 2001. Accordingly, the level of urbanization increased from 
below 8% in 1971 to 23% in 2001. The growth in the number of urban centers has also been 
phenomenal,  from  under  100  in  1971  to  522  in  1991  (and  most  likely  to  be  more  than  550  in 
2001). There has also been growth in the number of large urban centers: Cities with more than 
100,000 population have grown in number from 5 in 1971 to 25 in 2001. There were no “million 
cities”  in  Bangladesh  in  1961;  now  there  are  three,  with  Dhaka  emerging  as  a  megacity  with 
nearly 10 million people in its greater Statistical Metropolitan Area.  
 
2. 
Although  Bangladesh  presents  a  unique  case  of  dispersal  of  urban  centers  almost  in 
uniform  density  throughout  the  country  (with  the  exception  of  the  Chittagong  Hill  Tracts),  the 
distribution  is  far  from  being  a  balanced  one  by  city  size.  Certain  regions  suffer  from  the 
absence of large metropolitan centers, which could play the role of regional magnets or growth 
poles,  and  somewhat  reduce  the  strong  pull  effect  of  Dhaka.  Another  spatial  pattern  in  urban 
development  in  Bangladesh  is  the  recent  emergence  of  a  corridor  form  of  urban  expansion, 
radiating from Dhaka towards the west, north, northeast, and east, following the highways, and 
to the southeast along the water routes. Railways have played a complementary role to roads in 
the northern and northeastern corridors. 
 
B. 
 
3. 
In  terms  of  administrative  structure,  urban  centers  in  Bangladesh  are  classified  as  city 
corporations,  Pourashavas  (municipalities),  and  “other  urban  areas”  (which  are  run  under  the 
union  parishad  system).  The  present  number  of  city  corporations  is  4  (Dhaka,  Chittagong, 
Khulna, and Rajshahi), with two more Pourashavas to be upgraded to city corporations (Sylhet 
and Barisal), while the number of Pourashavas is now over 250 (growing from less than 120 in 
1996).  Municipal  governments  include  city  corporations  and  pourashavas.  All  municipal 
governments  operate  within  the  limits  set  by  relevant  ordinances  and  acts.  For  instance,  the 
Pourashava  Ordinance  of  1977  lays  down  the  foundation  of  pourashavas  and  their  functions, 
while  similar  ordinances  define  the  role,  power,  and  responsibilities  of  the  city  corporations. 
Besides  the  city  corporations  and  pourashavas,  some  special  development  authorities  and 
special purpose authorities were created to meet the growing demand for services based on two 
other ordinances − the Town Improvement Act of 1953 and the Sewerage Authority Ordinance 
of 1963. 
 
4. 
Corporations  and  Pourashavas  have  an  elected  head  (mayor  for  corporations  and 
chairperson for Pourashavas) and a council of commissioners who represent the people in each 
suburb  or  ward,  and  are  mandated  by  ordinance  to  provide  urban  services  including  (i) 
maintenance of roads, drainage, and parks; (ii) operation of water supply systems, community 
toilets,  markets,  solid  waste  management,  and  slaughterhouses;  (iii)  delivery  of  public  health 
and basic services for the urban poor; and (iv) development and building control. The executive 
power of a municipality rests with its chairperson or mayor who is the primary decision-maker. 
The chief executive officer is appointed by the Government but has only such executive powers 
as  the  chairperson  may  authorize.  All  officers  and  employees  of  the  Pourashava  are 
subordinate  to  chief  executive  officer.    Municipal  ordinances,  however,  contain  numerous 
clauses under which the Central Government can give directions to municipalities. In fact, only a 
few amendments have been made to the Pourashava Ordinance in the last 10 years, and even

these were all minor changes not sufficient to accord clear authority and decision-making power 
to local governments.  
 
C. 
 
5. 
Although the Government of Bangladesh has long been aware of both the rapid pace of 
urbanization in the country and the associated physical, economic, and social problems, it has 
not  yet  adopted  an  explicit  urban  policy.  However,  a  number  of  government  documents  and 
other  initiatives  have  from  time  to  time  indicated  the  policy  thinking  of  the  Government  with 
regard  to  urbanization  and  urban  development.  The  National  Report  on  Human  Settlements 
submitted  to  the  United  Nations  Habitat  I  Conference  held  at  Vancouver  in  Canada  in  1976 
came  close  to  a  policy  statement  on  human  settlements  and  urbanization  in  Bangladesh. 
Besides  this,  the  various  five-year  plan  documents  prepared  between  1973  and  1998  also 
indicated some policy direction.  
 
6. 
Overall, however, the formal planning documents have sidetracked urban development.. 
For instance, almost none of the plans developed through successive five-year plan exercises 
were  ever  implemented.  In  1991,  the  Planning  Commission  abandoned  the  sequence  of  five-
year plans and instead spent a lot of time to issue a 15-year Participatory Perspective Plan to 
be  supplemented  with  detailed  Annual  Development  Programs.  However,  the  Plan  was  never 
finalized,  and  the  five-year  planning  process  was  reestablished.  The  Fifth  Five-Year  Plan  has 
followed  more  or  less  the  earlier  policies  and  emphasized  decentralization  development. 
However,  investments  have  continued  to  be  concentrated  in  the  largest  cities,  Dhaka  and 
Chittagong.  On  the  other  hand,  a  number  of  parallel  developments  outside  the  five-year  plan 
exercises have emphasized urbanization and the urban sector. The Report of the Task Force on 
Social Implications of Urbanization prepared in 1991 at the behest of the interim government of 
the  time  made  an  elaborate  statement  on  urban  policy  and  poverty  reduction.  This  report, 
however,  was  not  approved  by  the  new  Government  and  therefore  not  considered  for 
implementation.  

7. 
Subsequently,  the  National  Housing  Policy  (1993),  the  Bangladesh  Urban  and  Shelter 
Sector  Review  (1993),  the  Bangladesh  Urban  Sector  National  Program  Document  (1994),  the 
Bangladesh  National  Habitat  II  Report  (1996),  and  the  recent  Bangladesh  National  Habitat  II 
Istanbul+5 Report (2001) have all underscored the most important role urbanization can play in 
national development. All these documents have spelled out policy directions and even action 
plans  for  achieving  a  balanced  development  process.  The  National  Housing  Policy  is  an 
officially approved document, and so are the 1996 Habitat II and 2001 Istanbul+5 Report. The 
Urban  Management  Policy  Statements  (1994  and  1999)  prepared  by  the  Ministry  of  Local 
Government (jointly with the Asian Development Bank and the World Bank) emphasized that all 
Pourashavas  should  have  adequate  personnel  and  financial  strength,  provide  and  maintain 
basic  infrastructure  facilities,  prepare  and  implement  land  use  plans,  address  poverty,  ensure 
participation and involve the private sector.

Contribution of the sector/subsector to reducing poverty in Bangladesh: 
 
The incidence of poverty, as measured by the costs of basic needs poverty line, fell from 58.8% in 1992 to 49.8% in 
2000. A sector breakdown of poverty shows that progress on reducing poverty incidence was almost equal across 
urban  and  rural  areas:  the  urban  headcount  rate  declined  from  44.9%  to  36.6%  (by  8.3%)  while  rural  poverty 
declined from 61.2% to 53.0% (by 8.2%). However, the moderate reduction in urban poverty during the last decade 
was accompanied by a notable increase in urban income inequality, as the Gini coefficient increased from 0.398 to 
0.452. 
 
The situations have been somewhat different in the case of absolute numbers of the poor in urban and rural areas. 
In  1992,  the  number  of  urban  poor  was  6.5  million  while  the  total  urban  population  was  14.6  million.  This  then 
increased to 9.3 million in 2000. Thus there was at least a 43% growth of the urban poor population during the last 
decade. The rural poor population, on the other hand, recorded a decline in its absolute number from 57.6 million to 
53.5  million.  The  principal  reason  behind  this  phenomenon  is  the  large-scale  shift  of  the  rural  population  to  the 
urban areas in the hope of better economic opportunities. The labor force in urban towns is composed primarily of 
migrants. It is also dominated by youth. The urban poor in the slums have very low levels of education and hardly 
any  skills.  About  40%  of  the  population  aged  5-15  years  are  not  attending  school.  Sixty  to  eighty  percent  of  the 
urban  labor  force  is  in  the  informal  sector  depending  on  the  size  of  the  city.  Female  migrants  in  small  towns  lack 
employment opportunities in both the formal and informal sector. An increasing number of urban poor especially the 
youth,  are  being  employed  in  socially  unproductive  or  unacceptable  occupations,  like  extortion,  begging,  and 
prostitution. 
 
If  the  current  trend  of  migration  continues,  the  urban  poor  will  increase  to  25-30%  of  the  total  country's  poor  by 
2020,  if  not  more.  This  points  to  the  growing  need  to  address  adverse  impacts  of  unplanned  and  uncontrolled 
urbanization and promote balanced urban development. In particular, the Asian Development Bank’s (ADB) urban 
sector  strategy  in  Bangladesh  has  recognized  the  strategic  importance  of  secondary  towns  in  the  urbanization 
process,  and  the  need  to  promote  them  to  lead  a  sound  and  balanced  urban  development.  The  concentration  of 
population and activities in a few metropolitan areas has aggravated urban environmental conditions in the absence 
of adequate capacities to manage urban growth. Recognizing diseconomies of congestion and deteriorating living 
conditions  of  the  urban  poor  in  metropolitan  cities,  ADB  has  already  provided  five  loans  totaling  $208  million  for 
urban  infrastructure  projects  in  secondary  towns  since  the  start  of  its  operations  in  Bangladesh  in  the  late  1980s. 
The proposed Project will further contribute to the achievements made so far by improving urban governance and 
infrastructure services in secondary towns.

existing  roads,  plus  some  road  widening.  There  is  no  new  road  construction.  In  all,  293 
individual schemes have been submitted by 21 Pourashavas for inclusion under phase 1. The 
cost  of  all  except  four  individual  schemes  is  well  below  the  ADB’s  cut-off  rate  for  analysis  of 
$200,000 (Tk11.6 million).  
 
While submitting the proposal for the road rehabilitation schemes, the Pourashavas were 
8. 
asked to carry out a 12-hour traffic count to support the need for the upgradation. Although the 
Pourashavas  have  submitted  a  broad  traffic  count  for  each  scheme,  their  reliability  cannot  be 
fully  assessed.  The  economic  analysis  therefore  has  been  carried  out  for  the  four  schemes 
costing  above  $200,000,  and  a  few  other  representative  schemes  to  demonstrate  their 
feasibility.  
 
9. 
The  improved  road  network  will  result  in  reduction  in  traffic  congestion  and  accidents, 
savings in travel time and vehicle operating costs, and safer conditions for pedestrians and non-
motorized  traffic.  The  main  objective  of  investment  in  urban  roads  is  to  reduce  user  costs  of 
different  vehicle  types,  which  means  the  reduction  of  cost  to  the  travelers  in  moving  from  one 
location to another.  
 
10. 
For  benefit  analysis,  vehicle  operating  costs  have  been  classified  into  the  following 
groups:  (i)  distance-dependent  costs,  which  vary  directly  with  distances  covered  (e.g., 
consumption of fuel, lubricants, wear and tear of tires, and repair and maintenance); (ii) speed-
dependent costs, which arise out of low speed because of poor/bad condition of roads; and (iii) 
time-dependent costs. 
 
11. 
In the secondary towns, the most prevalent vehicle type is the rickshaw, and these have 
therefore  been  considered  for  benefit  calculation.  The  difference  in  the  time  saved  due  to 
increased  speed  under  "without”  and  “with"  project  situations  was  allotted  a  time  value.  In  the 
without  project  situation,  pedalling  1  km  requires  12.5  minutes,  whereas  under  the  improved 
situation  the  required  time  would  be  reduced  to  7.5  minutes/km.  This  time  saved  after 
improvement would be available for additional trips, resulting in benefits. The saving has been 
converted into a benefit assuming that a rickshaw puller charges Tk3 per km.   
 
12. 
The  individual  EIRRs  assessed  for  the  selected  road  schemes  range  between  13.4% 
and 74.8% above the economic opportunity cost of capital, which is 12% for Bangladesh. The 
sensitivity  analysis  also  indicates  the  robustness  of  the  EIRR  with  respect  to  the  changes  in 
economic benefits and costs.

Water Supply 

 
C. 
 
13. 
A water supply component under the Project will generally involve rehabilitation of and 
extension  to  existing  systems.  Therefore,  the  incremental  volume  sold  will  be  calculated  by 
subtracting  the  estimated  existing  volume  sold  from  the  projected  annual  volume  sold.  To 
assess  the  financial  viability  of  a  typical  water  supply  component,  a  financial  evaluation  was 
prepared for the water supply component in Lakshmipur. The capacity of the existing production 
wells in the Pourashava is approximately 2,500 cubic meters per day or about 33% of the daily 
requirements, estimated at 7,500 cubic meters per day.  In terms of geographical coverage, the 
present water distribution network serves 2,280 out of 12,200 households. In view of the rapidly 
deteriorating situation, it is proposed to construct two production tubewells, a treatment plant, an 
overhead tank, and 8 km of distribution pipelines of 100-250 millimeters diameter at a total base 
cost of Tk36.1 million. 
 
14. 
The  subproject  will  be  funded  as  70%  loan  and  20%  grant  from  the  Government.  The 
Pourashava  will  meet  the  remaining  10%  from  its  own  resources.  The  loan  portion  will  carry 
interest at 7% with an amortization period of 20 years including the 5-year grace period.  
 
15. 
For revenue calculation, it is assumed that the water tariff will rise in real terms by 5% 
during the FY2003. Upon completion of the new scheme, the tariff will increase in real term by 
15%  in  the  year  of  commissioning  and  thereafter  by  5%  on  an  annual  basis.  The  incremental 
operating  cost  of  the  scheme  is  estimated  at  7%  of  the  cost  of  the  scheme.  Based  the 
incremental  revenue  and  costs,  the  base  FIRR  is  calculated  as  10.3%  compared  with  the 
weighted  average  cost  of  capital  of  6.1%.  Sensitivity  tests  indicate  that  the  FIRR  is  most 
sensitive to the decrease in revenue.   
 
16. 
The  field  visit  to  the  town  revealed  that  the  domestic  users  of  the  subconnections  are 
willing to pay more than the current water tariff payment of Tk150 per month provided the quality 
of  service  is  improved.  The  experience  from  other  externally  funded  projects  (e.g.,  the 
Netherlands  assistance  program)  shows  that  households  were  willing  to  pay  even  when  the 
charges were increased by 150% to a maximum 250%. When the tariff increase was 100%, the 
collection  efficiency  reached  as  high  as  79%.  An  affordability  analysis  shows  that  overall  the 
water supply charges  are affordable,  taking into account the low level of even median-income 
households.  The  percentage  of  median  income  required  to  pay  water  charges  would  be  no 
more than 4-5%.   
 
D. 
 
17. 
The solid waste service is paid for through the conservancy element of the holding tax, 
and  the  maximum  levy  permitted  under  Pourashava  Ordinance  is  7%  of  the  eligible  tax  base. 
Since all property holders must pay the tax, there are no incremental users of the service, and 
therefore no FIRR can be calculated. Instead, a cost recovery analysis has been carried out for 
all Pourashavas to assess the adequacy of revenues to recover the cost associated with solid 
waste  service  (except  for  Mehepur,  which  does  not  levy  the  conservancy  tax).  Revenues  are 
estimated by the conservancy element of the holding tax projections.  
 
18.  While  it  is  desirable  that  revenues  should  cover  all  costs,  including  depreciation  and 
recurrent  costs  for  O&M,  it  is  anticipated  that  only  eight  Pourashavas  will  achieve  full  cost 
recovery  without  a  significant  improvement  of  tax  revenues.  Since  the  poor  cost  recovery  is 
related to general problems with tax assessment and collection, during project implementation,

E. 
 
19. 
Financial  analyses  for  municipal  facilities  (e.g.,  transport  terminals,  markets,  and 
slaughterhouses)  are  prepared  in  consideration  of  the  Local  Government  Division’s  directive 
that,  while  Pourashavas  may  provide  these  services,  they  should  be  operated  by  the  private 
sector.  Revenues for these activities will be derived from leasing the facilities, and are based on 
investment  recovery  over  5  years,  plus  a  2%  real  annual  increase  of  rental  fee.  Costs  are 
associated with regular O&M of the facilities, estimated at 2.5% of fixed asset gross book value. 
The implementation period of the municipal facilities varies significantly: blocks of public toilets 
can be leased immediately upon completion; the construction of slaughterhouses will take one 
year,  truck  terminals  2  years,  and  bus  terminals  3  years  based  on  the  experience  with  the 
Secondary Towns Infrastructure Development Project  II.   
 
For  markets,  it  is  assumed  that  Pourashavas  will  lease  out  shops  to  individuals  rather 
20. 
than to a single leaseholder. Four different development levels are proposed (41, 62, 75, and 83 
shops), depending on the size of the Pourashava. It is estimated that 60% of the total floor area 
will  be  leased  out,  with  each  shop  having  a  floor  area  of  11.24  square  meters.  The  rental  per 
square meter is Tk200 per month, with a real annual increase of 2%. Additional income will be 
obtained from trade licenses, assessed at Tk500 per annum. O&M is 2.5% of fixed assets.  
 
21. 
Financial evaluations were prepared to develop different types of municipal facilities: The 
FIRR  is  estimated  at  12.9%  for  a  bus  terminal  in  Narsinghdi,  19.1%  for  a  slaughterhouse  in 
Narayanganji, and 14.5% for markets in Mehepur.   
 
F. 
 
22. 
The  slum  improvement  component  consists  of  provision  of  tubewells,  pit  latrines, 
dustbins and street lighting, plus construction of footpaths and microdrainage. The scope of the 
physical  investments  in  each  slum  area  is  based  on  the  number  of  low-income  households. 
Since most activities under the slum improvement component are aimed at reducing morbidity 
levels  through  the  introduction  of  higher  sanitation  standards,  one  of  the  benefits  could  be 
health  expenditure  savings.  However,  since  family  health  expenditure  data  collected  by  the 
socioeconomic  survey  are  not  entirely  reliable,  benefits  are  taken  in  the  form  of  productivity 
gains,  quantified  as  follows:  (i)  10  working  days  equivalent  gained  by  the  wage  earner,  (ii)  10 
working days equivalent gained by the housekeeper from reduced child morbidity levels, and (iii) 
30 minutes per day saved by women due to the closer proximity of clean piped water supplies.  
For  economic  analysis,  it  is  conservatively  assumed  that  the  economic  value  of  the  nonwage 
earner’s time is 20% of the wage earner’s income. Despite this relatively modest evaluation of 
productivity  gains,  the  base  EIRRs  for  all  22  towns  were  estimated  above  the  cut-off  rate  of 
12%.
